Dear JILL SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing

Traverse City, MI 49684

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
**WARNING, THIS REPORT CONTAINS QUOTED PROFANITY**
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001613
Special Investigation Intake Date: July 23, 2024
License #: CB410245705
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL CHRISTINE SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: JILL CHRISTINE SCHREUDER
Agency Name: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
GR
Agency Address: 40 JEFFERSON AVE
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49503-4304
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/19/2025

1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff responsibilities
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care agency did not provide adequate support upon placing
a youth in a foster home. There were multiple incidents where the
foster care worker did not maintain an appropriate line of
communication with the foster parent or communicate needed
information to ensure the youth's mental/medical needs were met
timely.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 8, 2024.
They reported they had no additional information.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on August 14, 2024. Foster Parent (FP) and the agency
she is licensed through is not someone they have worked with in
the past. Their care coordinator through West Michigan
Partnership for Children (WMPC) is part of a foster parent
Facebook group and is a foster parent herself. She saw FP had
posted something about her house is open to teens and there was
some correspondence after that. FP indicated she was interested
in hearing more about Youth A and provided her license number
and licensing agency contact information. A full disclosure
meeting was held, and an open conversation took place between
FP, Licensing Worker, FC Supervisor and Foster Care Worker
(FCW) that included discussions regarding Youth A’s needs,
struggles, where they’re at and where they’re going with things as
well as answered any of FP’s questions. At the conclusion of the
meeting FP indicated she wanted to move forward with placement
of Youth A.
2

Upon placement, services were arranged with Community Mental
Health (CMH), this included medication management and an
enhanced foster care and behavioral specialist that works directly
with Youth A. FC Supervisor stated FP received a considerable
number of services and support during the time Youth A was
placed there, which was less than one month.
Youth A had been at Pine Rest for two weeks prior to placement
with FP. Upon his discharge, Pine Rest provided FCW with a 30-
day supply of Youth A’s medications and this was provided to FP.
About 17 or 18 days into placement FP notified FCW that Youth A
was out of his medications. FCW stated this couldn’t be accurate
because she was provided a 30-day supply. FCW confirmed the
30-day supply with Pine Rest when she picked up Youth A but did
not count them herself. FP became upset and indicated the
agency never sent him with enough medication and that is what
caused his escalated behavior. FC Supervisor believes FP waited
multiple days of Youth A being out of his medication before she
notified FCW that he was out. FP had two other teenagers placed
in her home while Youth A was placed there. There is concern FP
did not monitor the medications appropriately and that is why they
are missing. Additionally, there is suspicion one of the other
youths in the home may have taken them.
FC Supervisor stated he had regular conversations with FCW
regarding this case. He stated FP was insistent on getting a call
back immediately after leaving a message and would call or text
repeatedly. FP was provided the on-call number more than once
and then continued to call FCW after hours or on weekends and
was upset when she didn’t receive a timely response. She was
reminded to call the on call number after hours.
FC Supervisor stated the agency provided much support to FP.
Youth A is a challenging youth and there much effort and supports
that go along with him, therefore it’s frustrating to hear complaints
about the agency dumping him without his belongings,
medications or supports.
FP immediately asked for reimbursement for damage Youth A did
to her home. She sent the agency a list of items he broke that
needed to be replaced, but this was a list and a price with no
documentation providing verification of prices. For example, the
list contained a reimbursement request for a $150 lamp and FP
wanted money right away. For the windows that were broken, FC
Supervisor reached out to the Licensing Agency Supervisor and
Program Manager (PM) 7-8 times requesting to meet to discuss if
3

FIG could assist, but he never heard back from anyone.
Eventually he went to his supervisor and asked her to get involved
due to the lack of response.
FP refused to allow agency to pick up his belongings when he left.
The agency finally obtained Youth A’s clothes back, but two pairs
of expensive Jordan brand shoes were missing.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
August 14, 2024. Prior to placement with FP, Youth A was at Pine
Rest. He was placed with FP on 6/27/2024. The agency had a full
disclosure meeting with FP where they discussed all of his
behaviors and FP knew he was coming from Pine Rest. Upon
picking him up at Pine Rest to transport to FP’s home, they were
given his medication. He was given a 30-day supply of his
medication and this was in the original containers in the pharmacy
bags which were closed and stapled to the bag. It included a
prescription chart that specified what he was given that day and
what needs to be given that night. They went directly from Pine
Rest to FP’s home and the medication was not opened or touched
from the time they dropped off Youth A. When FP stated on day
17 or 18 of the placement, she didn’t have enough medication,
FCW contacted the social worker at Pine Rest to verify he was
given a 30-day supply, which was confirmed. FP reported to FCW
she mixed up Youth A’s prescription with another youth that had
been placed in her home. FCW stated this was confusing and she
could not understand how he could be out of his medication this
early. FCW stated Youth A had a psychiatric appointment near
FP’s home on 7/22/2024 to get an updated prescription refill.
Youth A was on Vyvanse, Melatonin, Abilify and Hydroxyzine. He
was short of the Abilify. Youth A reported to FCW that sometimes
he needed to remind FP to give it to him and the medications were
stored in the FP’s bedroom. She stated Youth A is aware of what
medications he is taking, the dose, how often he needs to take
them and what they do for him. FCW became aware Youth A was
down to 5-6 pills, however a day or two later FP reported Youth A
was out of his medications. There were concerns because it didn’t
make sense based on the amount FP reported he had left and the
amount he takes per day.
FCW stated she went over the placement paperwork with FP and
obtained signatures and dates verifying this. Since this was a
borrowed bed placement, FP also signed a borrowed bed contract
the same day. A thorough walk through was also completed. FCW
4

acknowledged she stated they didn’t plan on staying too long
because they had been traveling since 8am that day and still had
a 3-hour drive home. She stated they reviewed a safety plan with
Youth A and indicated he advocates well for himself and is aware
of what his triggers are.
Youth A received Enhanced Foster Care (EFC) services.
Someone from the agency was contacting FP every day or every
other day to provide support due to his needs. FP reported to the
agency they were getting on her nerves and calling too much. She
refused to allow the behavioral specialist to come to the home to
work with Youth A, but reported to the licensing worker the agency
is not contacting or supporting her. At one point, FP no longer
wanted EFC services and felt based on her experience and
education she could manage without those services.
FCW had advised that Youth A could display challenging
behaviors especially after being told no, but FP didn’t want to hear
this. She felt based on her education and experience she could
manage him. On 7/18/2024 he destroyed FP house and was
taken to a hospital. FP reported Youth A was no longer welcome
in her home. EFC worker was on her way to pick him up, but FP
agreed to keep him only after an increase in funds. Upon returning
to FP’s home, Youth A ran away again and got into an altercation.
FCW stated Youth A does display negative behaviors, but he
historically will admit to his behaviors and the reasons behind it.
FCW reported Youth A admitted he pulled a knife on FP, but it
was because FP reported to police Youth A was attempting to
harm himself and this wasn’t true. He said, “bitch I’m going to kill
you” and then he dropped the knife. He was then taken back to
the hospital and another placement was located.
FP sent an email that stated he broke two lamps and a phone
charger that listed prices but didn’t have estimates or invoices.
She stated there were damaged windows that the agency
requested an invoice for. FP didn’t return all of Youth A’s shoes
including some expensive ones and Youth A was very upset about
his missing shoes. She stated Youth A left with them, but he only
had a pair of crocs that he was wearing and nothing else. The
agency had difficulty getting Youth A’s clothes. She stated they
were in FP’s area on 7/22/2024 for Youth A’s psychological
appointment and FCW texted Licensing Worker indicating she
would be in town and asked if she could pick up Youth A’s clothes
and then meet to get his belongings. Licensing Worker said no,
and they would need to make an appointment. FP then contacted
FCW and said Licensing worker stated you were driving by FP
5

house, and you need to make an appointment and she wasn’t
available until 8/3/2024 or 8/5/2024.
Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on August 21,
2024 via telephone. A follow up discussion took place via
telephone on September 6, 2024. FP stated FCW and EFC
brought Youth A to her house. Upon arriving, FCW stated they
wouldn’t be there long. Youth A introduced himself and asked to
review his safety plan with FP and identified his triggers. FP stated
she will review with FCW and FCW said no that was reviewed with
Youth A and he knows what triggers him. Youth A wanted to see
his room and FP reported FCW didn’t want to see it. Eventually
she peeked in but didn’t enter which FP found odd. FP stated EFC
worker observed it as well. As they were returning downstairs
FCW said they were getting ready to leave and walked out and
Youth A ran after her because she left without saying anything to
him. As they were leaving, FCW provided the medication to FP.
The bag was used and opened with no staple on it. FP stated she
wasn’t provided a medical passport, placement outline or much
information about Youth A’s behaviors. FP stated she was
provided a medical authorization form. She stated she signed
many documents but felt rushed by FCW. A few days into
placement she inquired about Youth A’s medical appointments.
She stated she attempted to reach out several times and FCW
wasn’t communicating.
Youth A was being respectful, following instructions and cleaning
and bathing himself. She noticed there was a difference in the
amount of medication for each bottle. She said FCW indicated she
would call the pharmacy and doctor to obtain more. A week later
he was out of his medication. FP stated she contacted people at
her agency and asked if they would reach out to FCW. She
contacted EFC as well, but another week went by without
medication, and this is when Youth A’s behaviors escalated.
Youth A lost at a video game and became frustrated and started
to escalate. He hit her dog with a tablet, swore at FP and kicked
her in the leg. She texted FCW and stated she needed help and
Youth A was making self-harming statements.
FP stated Youth A stole money and a vape from relatives at her
father’s birthday party. She said she reported to FCW, and FCW
said Youth A has a history of smoking marijuana and FP asked
why no one had explained that to her previously. Youth A and
another youth from the birthday party, blamed each other but she
said it was Youth A. In the same day, Youth A ran away and took
three pairs of his shoes and came back with $1. She called Law
6

Enforcement and the agency on call to let them know Youth A had
returned. She also called FCW, but she didn’t answer.
On 7/19/2024 Youth A began destroying her property by breaking
her windows. She called and texted FCW and she was told she
was in a meeting. FP asked for her supervisor, and she was told
by FCW that he was in a meeting as well. She called her licensing
worker who advised her to call LE and the on-call worker. Youth A
was making suicidal statements and locked the door of the room
he was in. She stated he broke some of her lamps, her son’s
headphones and damaged an Xbox. Law enforcement arrived and
took Youth A to the hospital while FP followed. She called FCW
from the hospital and asked for help and said Youth A cannot
come back to her home. FCW put her on hold and called the
charge nurse and informed her that FP signed a document that
states she is required to provide a 14-day notice.
FP did agree to allow Youth A to return home with her. Upon
returning to FP’s home, Youth A jumped out of the car and left the
area. FP contacted law enforcement and Youth A returned on his
own. Youth A picked up a brick and broke windows to the FP
home. Youth A asked to use the bathroom and threatened to kill
FP and took a knife and charged towards FP while yelling threats.
Law enforcement intercepted and took the knife away and
subdued him.
Enhanced Foster Care worker (EFC worker) was interviewed
via telephone on August 28, 2024. EFC worker stated she
accompanied FCW to pick up Youth A from Pine Rest to transport
him to FP’s house on June 27, 2024. Youth A’s medication was in
a plastic bag that was stapled shut and was delivered to FP as is.
Pine Rest confirmed there was a 30-day supply of Youth A’s
medication. EFC worker found it concerning regarding the
medication because FP’s story changed a few times. FP initially
reported Youth A was almost out of all his medications and then
FP said Youth A was completely out of one medication and then
stated she confused Youth A with another youth that had been
placed in her home.
Upon arriving at FP’s house, they went over intake paperwork and
provided Youth A’s medication that was provided by Pine Rest. FP
provided a tour of her home and they were able to view the room
Youth A would be sleeping in and did not have any concerns. EFC
worker stated she and FCW sat down for quite a while with FP
and reviewed each document and then obtained signatures when
needed. A safety plan was reviewed as well, and Youth A read the
7

majority of it. He was also knowledgeable about the medication he
took and dosage.
EFC worker stated she communicated with FP regularly to check
in. She stated FP didn’t usually initiate contact with her. She
conducted a meeting with FP after placement and it went well but
afterwards, she stated FP seemed to be annoyed by her
communication attempts.
Video Reviewed:
• FP provided a video she recorded. The date is not
displayed but FP reports the date to be 7/19/2024. Video is
taken from outside FP’s residence and shows Youth A
breaking a window from inside a second story bedroom.
Items are being thrown out the window.
Documents reviewed:
• Replacement checklist dated 6/27/2024 that lists
replacement outline, medical passport, emergency
authorization card, school letter and placement letter
(among others).
• Replacement outline signed by FCW and FP and dated
6/27/2024. Youth A’s immediate concerns: lack of adequate
clothing, delinquent record, aggressive/assaultive and
runaway risk.
A list of current medications for Youth A.
Supervision needs/behavior management: Youth A
requires additional supervision due to being an AWOL risk.
Youth A may run away when he is upset.
Any other available information: if Youth A is escalated,
please give him space to cool down.
• Medical passport signed by FCW and FP, dated 6/27/2024.
• Text message sent from FCW to FP on 6/28/2024 providing
the agency on-call phone number.
• Youth A MISACWIS file: 6/27/2024 social work contact-
Worker and EFC worker went to pick up Youth A from Pine
Rest to take him to his new foster home placement. On the
way to placement, Youth A stated he was excited to be out
of Pine Rest and that he is looking forward to meeting his
new foster family.
FCW completed move paperwork with FP. This worker
went over medications with FP and Youth A. Youth A
stated he does not have a problem taking them and that he
is feeling fine being on them. A safety walk through of the
home was completed there were no safety concerns. Youth
8

A has his own room with an age-appropriate bed. Youth A
went over his safety plan and triggers with FP.
Before the visit was over, FCW and Youth A had a private
conversation about how he felt and what was going through
his head. Youth A stated he liked his room and the foster
family seems nice. He said he is comfortable. FCW said
goodbye and left.
• MISACWIS provider records for FP show Youth A was
played in her home from 6/27/2024-7/19/2024.
• Text messages between FP and FCW and FP and EFC
were reviewed. FP contacts FCW regarding some
issues/questions regarding Youth A. The majority of the
correspondence is regarding his upcoming appointments
and behaviors. Other than one exchange where FCW
indicates she and FC supervisor are in a staff meeting, a
response is provided to the inquiries. Some of the contact
sent from FP to FCW and EFCW is after hours. Contact
between FP and on-call staff was not provided.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. The agency provided
information and documentation that detailed Youth A’s behavioral
history and current needs to FP prior to his placement in her
home. Based on review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file,
interviews with staff and text messages, enhanced foster care
services were provided to assist Youth A and FP based on his
needs however, FP asked the agency to discontinue services. In
addition, there is insufficient evidence to show the agency did not
act on concerns reported by FP.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
___________________________________9/11/2024________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
9/25/2024

Area Manager
10
